The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?

Comments_List: Understanding of the complexities of regulation
I gained an appreciation for the legal perspective of energy, which i hadn't encountered in my other coursework. This additional way of seeing my discipline was very valuable.
Had no legal background, got an overview of some energy regulation.

I learned nothing from this class. There was no course material other than the professor telling stories that were not related to the regulation of energy extraction. The only time I learned anything from this class was when I was doing research for my paper.

I felt like the class fell below my expectations. The first half of the course was usually devoted to general energy concepts that I have learned before with the second half a discussion on these concepts with many tangents. I was hoping to gain substantial knowledge on complex energy laws but I feel that it was not taught in an organized fashion.

did not align with expectations. The class was a broad overview of energy policy, rather than specifically talking about the regulation of energy, which is what the class is advertised to cover. For example, I know what LNG is and how it is shipped, but I still have no clue what the United States' regulation of LNG is
About par
The course met my expectations as a survey in energy law. I particularly enjoyed how the discussions we had were high level and about the real implications of the law.
More philosophical and theoretical that I thought going into the class.
I was disappointed with the course.  I felt like lectures were often scattered, and disorganized.

This course was a complete disappointment, and I believe the University should seriously consider reevaluating this course or dropping it. The course was titled "Regulation of Energy Extraction." From this title, I expected to learn about the laws and regulations surrounding coal, oil, and gas extraction. Instead, none of the lectures even remotely touched upon regulation surrounding these, but instead the professor would tell stories about the environmental impacts of different energy forms. Most of the students in the class are energy students and are very familiar with the general environmental impacts of energy forms already, and as a result this class was a complete waste of time. We spent an entire three classes discussing renewable energy technologies which has absolutely nothing to do with the regulation of energy extraction.

Better organization for educating students on law issues. The current format of going long dialogues with some policy relevance did not present a coherent lesson that students could learn. I also think some things that the professor presented as facts were false.

The instructor did a good job making the course accessible for non-law students--I really appreciated that. I think the instructor could allow students a little more space for discussion in class. It often felt like a lecture.
More guidance on paper expectations.

Strengths: 1) The set up of the class (i.e., dedicating a class period or 2 to each energy industry)
2) The diversity in readings in terms of both perspectives and type of publication

Weaknesses: 1) I think this course could have benefitted from more discussion - the diverse perspectives in the room due to students from many different graduate schools taking the course would have made for very interesting and insightful discussions. 
2) Check the links to your readings.  It is incredibly frustrating when you are trying to do the readings for the course and links are broken.
3) Update the readings.  A lot of the news articles were 5+ years old.  There are more recent, similar sources.

The professor would occasionally start good discussions requiring students to think critically about how to solve energy-related problems. However, these were typically not related to what the course should have been about.

Only take this course if you would like to receive general knowledge of energy in the US. If you have taken energy course before, do not think that this course adds to that with a specific focus on energy policy and laws only.
I don't recommend it. Other classes give a better overview of energy policy if that's what you're looking to get from this class.
This course has a relatively light workload and is a good way to experience a law course, if you only ever have the chance to take one.

I would not recommend this course to other students.  The topics covered in the course, the syllabus, and the readings all made this class sound super appealing.  I was disappointed though in what I got out of it overall.
I would not advise a student to take this class. It was incredibly poorly organized, taught, and completely lacking in substance. Waste of time.
